PERSONAE.TITLE: Dramatis Personae
PERSONAE.PERSONA: PARIS, a young nobleman, kinsman to the prince.

PGROUP.GRPDESCR: heads of two houses at variance with each other.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: An old man, cousin to Capulet.
MERCUTIO, kinsman to the prince, and friend to Romeo.
BENVOLIO, nephew to Montague, and friend to Romeo.
Page to Paris; another Page; an officer.
Citizens of Verona; several Men and Women, relations to both houses; Maskers, Guards, Watchmen, and Attendants.

SPEECH.LINE: Two households, both alike in dignity,
In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
From ancient grudge break to new mutiny,
Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean.
From forth the fatal loins of these two foes
A pair of star-cross'd lovers take their life;
Whole misadventured piteous overthrows
Do with their death bury their parents' strife.
The fearful passage of their death-mark'd love,
And the continuance of their parents' rage,
Which, but their children's end, nought could remove,
Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage;
The which if you with patient ears attend,
What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. Verona. A public place.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY, of the house of Capulet, armed with swords and bucklers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: No, for then we should be colliers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: I strike quickly, being moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:
therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will
take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes
to the wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,
are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push
Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids
to the wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I
have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the
maids, and cut off their heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: The heads of the maids?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;
take it in what sense thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: They must take it in sense that feel it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and
'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou
hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes
two of the house of the Montagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: How! turn thy back and run?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Fear me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: No, marry; I fear thee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as
they list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;
which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ABRAHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: I do bite my thumb, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ABRAHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Aside to GREGORY Is the law of our side, if I say
ay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I
bite my thumb, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: Do you quarrel, sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ABRAHAM
SPEECH.LINE: Quarrel sir! no, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ABRAHAM
SPEECH.LINE: No better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GREGORY
SPEECH.LINE: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, better, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ABRAHAM
SPEECH.LINE: You lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SAMPSON
SPEECH.LINE: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Part, fools!
Put up your swords; you know not what you do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,
Or manage it to part these men with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,
As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:
Have at thee, coward!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter, several of both houses, who join the fray; then enter Citizens, with clubs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Citizen
SPEECH.LINE: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!
Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CAPULET in his gown, and LADY CAPULET

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,
And flourishes his blade in spite of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PRINCE
SPEECH.LINE: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--
Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,
That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
With purple fountains issuing from your veins,
On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,
And hear the sentence of your moved prince.
Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,
By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,
And made Verona's ancient citizens
Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,
To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:
If ever you disturb our streets again,
Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
For this time, all the rest depart away:
You Capulet; shall go along with me:
And, Montague, come you this afternoon,
To know our further pleasure in this case,
To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.
Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but MONTAGUE, LADY MONTAGUE, and BENVOLIO

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Here were the servants of your adversary,
And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:
I drew to part them: in the instant came
The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,
Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,
He swung about his head and cut the winds,
Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,
Came more and more and fought on part and part,
Till the prince came, who parted either part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?
Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun
Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,
A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;
Where, underneath the grove of sycamore
That westward rooteth from the city's side,
So early walking did I see your son:
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me
And stole into the covert of the wood:
I, measuring his affections by my own,
That most are busied when they're most alone,
Pursued my humour not pursuing his,
And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Many a morning hath he there been seen,
With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.
Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
Should in the furthest east begin to draw
The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,
Away from the light steals home my heavy son,
And private in his chamber pens himself,
Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out
And makes himself an artificial night:
Black and portentous must this humour prove,
Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Have you importuned him by any means?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: Both by myself and many other friends:
But he, his own affections' counsellor,
Is to himself--I will not say how true--
But to himself so secret and so close,
So far from sounding and discovery,
As is the bud bit with an envious worm,
Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.
We would as willingly give cure as know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;
I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MONTAGUE
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,
To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Good-morrow, cousin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Is the day so young?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: But new struck nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me! sad hours seem long.
Was that my father that went hence so fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: In love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Out--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Of love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Out of her favour, where I am in love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,
Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,
Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!
Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?
Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.
Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
O any thing, of nothing first create!
O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,
sick health!
Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!
This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
Dost thou not laugh?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: No, coz, I rather weep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Good heart, at what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: At thy good heart's oppression.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, such is love's transgression.
Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest
With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;
Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;
Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:
What is it else? a madness most discreet,
A choking gall and a preserving sweet.
Farewell, my coz.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Soft! I will go along;
An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;
This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Groan! why, no.
But sadly tell me who.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:
Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!
In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit
With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;
And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,
From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
She will not stay the siege of loving terms,
Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,
Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,
That when she dies with beauty dies her store.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,
For beauty starved with her severity
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
To merit bliss by making me despair:
She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow
Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O, teach me how I should forget to think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: By giving liberty unto thine eyes;
Examine other beauties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis the way
To call hers exquisite, in question more:
These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows
Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;
He that is strucken blind cannot forget
The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:
Show me a mistress that is passing fair,
What doth her beauty serve, but as a note
Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?
Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: But Montague is bound as well as I,
In penalty alike; and 'tis not hard, I think,
For men so old as we to keep the peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PARIS
SPEECH.LINE: Of honourable reckoning are you both;
And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.
But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: But saying o'er what I have said before:
My child is yet a stranger in the world;
She hath not seen the change of fourteen years,
Let two more summers wither in their pride,
Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PARIS
SPEECH.LINE: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: And too soon marr'd are those so early made.
The earth hath swallow'd all my hopes but she,
She is the hopeful lady of my earth:
But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart,
My will to her consent is but a part;
An she agree, within her scope of choice
Lies my consent and fair according voice.
This night I hold an old accustom'd feast,
Whereto I have invited many a guest,
Such as I love; and you, among the store,
One more, most welcome, makes my number more.
At my poor house look to behold this night
Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:
Such comfort as do lusty young men feel
When well-apparell'd April on the heel
Of limping winter treads, even such delight
Among fresh female buds shall you this night
Inherit at my house; hear all, all see,
And like her most whose merit most shall be:
Which on more view, of many mine being one
May stand in number, though in reckoning none,
Come, go with me.
Go, sirrah, trudge about
Through fair Verona; find those persons out
Whose names are written there, and to them say,
My house and welcome on their pleasure stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Find them out whose names are written here! It is
written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his
yard, and the tailor with his last, the fisher with
his pencil, and the painter with his nets; but I am
sent to find those persons whose names are here
writ, and can never find what names the writing
person hath here writ. I must to the learned.--In good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, man, one fire burns out another's burning,
One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish;
Turn giddy, and be holp by backward turning;
One desperate grief cures with another's languish:
Take thou some new infection to thy eye,
And the rank poison of the old will die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Your plaintain-leaf is excellent for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: For what, I pray thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: For your broken shin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Romeo, art thou mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is;
Shut up in prison, kept without my food,
Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Perhaps you have learned it without book: but, I
pray, can you read any thing you see?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Ye say honestly: rest you merry!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, fellow; I can read.
'Signior Martino and his wife and daughters;
County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady
widow of Vitravio; Signior Placentio and his lovely
nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; mine
uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; my fair niece
Rosaline; Livia; Signior Valentio and his cousin
Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.' A fair
assembly: whither should they come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Whither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: To supper; to our house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Whose house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: My master's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, I should have ask'd you that before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the
great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house
of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine.
Rest you merry!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: At this same ancient feast of Capulet's
Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest,
With all the admired beauties of Verona:
Go thither; and, with unattainted eye,
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: When the devout religion of mine eye
Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires;
And these, who often drown'd could never die,
Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!
One fairer than my love! the all-seeing sun
Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by,
Herself poised with herself in either eye:
But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd
Your lady's love against some other maid
That I will show you shining at this feast,
And she shall scant show well that now shows best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown,
But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. A room in Capulet's house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Nurse, where's my daughter? call her forth to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Now, by my maidenhead, at twelve year old,
I bade her come. What, lamb! what, ladybird!
God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: How now! who calls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Your mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I am here.
What is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: This is the matter:--Nurse, give leave awhile,
We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again;
I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel.
Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: She's not fourteen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: I'll lay fourteen of my teeth,--
And yet, to my teeth be it spoken, I have but four--
She is not fourteen. How long is it now
To Lammas-tide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: A fortnight and odd days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Even or odd, of all days in the year,
Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen.
Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!--
Were of an age: well, Susan is with God;
She was too good for me: but, as I said,
On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen;
That shall she, marry; I remember it well.
'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;
And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,--
Of all the days of the year, upon that day:
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,
Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall;
My lord and you were then at Mantua:--
Nay, I do bear a brain:--but, as I said,
When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple
Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool,
To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
Shake quoth the dove-house: 'twas no need, I trow,
To bid me trudge:
And since that time it is eleven years;
For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood,
She could have run and waddled all about;
For even the day before, she broke her brow:
And then my husband--God be with his soul!
A' was a merry man--took up the child:
'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?
Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;
Wilt thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidame,
The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay.'
To see, now, how a jest shall come about!
I warrant, an I should live a thousand years,
I never should forget it: 'Wilt thou not, Jule?' quoth he;
And, pretty fool, it stinted and said 'Ay.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh,
To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.'
And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow
A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone;
A parlous knock; and it cried bitterly:
'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face?
Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age;
Wilt thou not, Jule?' it stinted and said 'Ay.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I have done. God mark thee to his grace!
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed:
An I might live to see thee married once,
I have my wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, that 'marry' is the very theme
I came to talk of. Tell me, daughter Juliet,
How stands your disposition to be married?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: It is an honour that I dream not of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: An honour! were not I thine only nurse,
I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Well, think of marriage now; younger than you,
Here in Verona, ladies of esteem,
Are made already mothers: by my count,
I was your mother much upon these years
That you are now a maid. Thus then in brief:
The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: A man, young lady! lady, such a man
As all the world--why, he's a man of wax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Verona's summer hath not such a flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: What say you? can you love the gentleman?
This night you shall behold him at our feast;
Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face,
And find delight writ there with beauty's pen;
Examine every married lineament,
And see how one another lends content
And what obscured in this fair volume lies
Find written in the margent of his eyes.
This precious book of love, this unbound lover,
To beautify him, only lacks a cover:
The fish lives in the sea, and 'tis much pride
For fair without the fair within to hide:
That book in many's eyes doth share the glory,
That in gold clasps locks in the golden story;
So shall you share all that he doth possess,
By having him, making yourself no less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: No less! nay, bigger; women grow by men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Speak briefly, can you like of Paris' love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I'll look to like, if looking liking move:
But no more deep will I endart mine eye
Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you
called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in
the pantry, and every thing in extremity. I must
hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LADY CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: We follow thee.
Juliet, the county stays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE IV. A street.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter ROMEO, MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, with five or six Maskers, Torch-bearers, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
Or shall we on without a apology?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: The date is out of such prolixity:
We'll have no Cupid hoodwink'd with a scarf,
Bearing a Tartar's painted bow of lath,
Scaring the ladies like a crow-keeper;
Nor no without-book prologue, faintly spoke
After the prompter, for our entrance:
But let them measure us by what they will;
We'll measure them a measure, and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;
Being but heavy, I will bear the light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, believe me: you have dancing shoes
With nimble soles: I have a soul of lead
So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: You are a lover; borrow Cupid's wings,
And soar with them above a common bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft
To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,
I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe:
Under love's heavy burden do I sink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: And, to sink in it, should you burden love;
Too great oppression for a tender thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Is love a tender thing? it is too rough,
Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: If love be rough with you, be rough with love;
Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.
Give me a case to put my visage in:
A visor for a visor! what care I
What curious eye doth quote deformities?
Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in,
But every man betake him to his legs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: A torch for me: let wantons light of heart
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,
For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase;
I'll be a candle-holder, and look on.
The game was ne'er so fair, and I am done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, dun's the mouse, the constable's own word:
If thou art dun, we'll draw thee from the mire
Of this sir-reverence love, wherein thou stick'st
Up to the ears. Come, we burn daylight, ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that's not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: I mean, sir, in delay
We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.
Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits
Five times in that ere once in our five wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: And we mean well in going to this mask;
But 'tis no wit to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, may one ask?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I dream'd a dream to-night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: And so did I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what was yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: That dreamers often lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: O, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes
In shape no bigger than an agate-stone
On the fore-finger of an alderman,
Drawn with a team of little atomies
Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;
Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs,
The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,
The traces of the smallest spider's web,
The collars of the moonshine's watery beams,
Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film,
Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat,
Not so big as a round little worm
Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;
Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut
Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,
Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.
And in this state she gallops night by night
Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;
O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,
O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees,
O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,
Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,
Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:
Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,
And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;
And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail
Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,
Then dreams, he of another benefice:
Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck,
And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,
Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon
Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,
And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two
And sleeps again. This is that very Mab
That plats the manes of horses in the night,
And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,
Which once untangled, much misfortune bodes:
This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs,
That presses them and learns them first to bear,
Making them women of good carriage:
This is she--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
Thou talk'st of nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: True, I talk of dreams,
Which are the children of an idle brain,
Begot of nothing but vain fantasy,
Which is as thin of substance as the air
And more inconstant than the wind, who wooes
Even now the frozen bosom of the north,
And, being anger'd, puffs away from thence,
Turning his face to the dew-dropping south.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: This wind, you talk of, blows us from ourselves;
Supper is done, and we shall come too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I fear, too early: for my mind misgives
Some consequence yet hanging in the stars
Shall bitterly begin his fearful date
With this night's revels and expire the term
Of a despised life closed in my breast
By some vile forfeit of untimely death.
But He, that hath the steerage of my course,
Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Strike, drum.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE V. A hall in Capulet's house.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Musicians waiting. Enter Servingmen with napkins

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Potpan, that he helps not to take away? He
shift a trencher? he scrape a trencher!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Servant
SPEECH.LINE: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men's
hands and they unwashed too, 'tis a foul thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Away with the joint-stools, remove the
court-cupboard, look to the plate. Good thou, save
me a piece of marchpane; and, as thou lovest me, let
the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.
Antony, and Potpan!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Servant
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, boy, ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: First Servant
SPEECH.LINE: You are looked for and called for, asked for and
sought for, in the great chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Servant
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot be here and there too. Cheerly, boys; be
brisk awhile, and the longer liver take all.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter CAPULET, with JULIET and others of his house, meeting the Guests and Maskers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, gentlemen! ladies that have their toes
Unplagued with corns will have a bout with you.
Ah ha, my mistresses! which of you all
Will now deny to dance? she that makes dainty,
She, I'll swear, hath corns; am I come near ye now?
Welcome, gentlemen! I have seen the day
That I have worn a visor and could tell
A whispering tale in a fair lady's ear,
Such as would please: 'tis gone, 'tis gone, 'tis gone:
You are welcome, gentlemen! come, musicians, play.
A hall, a hall! give room! and foot it, girls.
More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up,
And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.
Ah, sirrah, this unlook'd-for sport comes well.
Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet;
For you and I are past our dancing days:
How long is't now since last yourself and I
Were in a mask?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Capulet
SPEECH.LINE: By'r lady, thirty years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: What, man! 'tis not so much, 'tis not so much:
'Tis since the nuptials of Lucentio,
Come pentecost as quickly as it will,
Some five and twenty years; and then we mask'd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Second Capulet
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir;
His son is thirty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Will you tell me that?
His son was but a ward two years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: To a Servingman What lady is that, which doth
enrich the hand
Of yonder knight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Servant
SPEECH.LINE: I know not, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night
Like a rich jewel in an Ethiope's ear;
Beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear!
So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows,
As yonder lady o'er her fellows shows.
The measure done, I'll watch her place of stand,
And, touching hers, make blessed my rude hand.
Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight!
For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.
Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave
Come hither, cover'd with an antic face,
To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
Now, by the stock and honour of my kin,
To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how now, kinsman! wherefore storm you so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,
A villain that is hither come in spite,
To scorn at our solemnity this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Young Romeo is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis he, that villain Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone;
He bears him like a portly gentleman;
And, to say truth, Verona brags of him
To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:
I would not for the wealth of all the town
Here in my house do him disparagement:
Therefore be patient, take no note of him:
It is my will, the which if thou respect,
Show a fair presence and put off these frowns,
And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: It fits, when such a villain is a guest:
I'll not endure him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: He shall be endured:
What, goodman boy! I say, he shall: go to;
Am I the master here, or you? go to.
You'll not endure him! God shall mend my soul!
You'll make a mutiny among my guests!
You will set cock-a-hoop! you'll be the man!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Why, uncle, 'tis a shame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Go to, go to;
You are a saucy boy: is't so, indeed?
This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what:
You must contrary me! marry, 'tis time.
Well said, my hearts! You are a princox; go:
Be quiet, or--More light, more light! For shame!
I'll make you quiet. What, cheerly, my hearts!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Patience perforce with wilful choler meeting
Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.
I will withdraw: but this intrusion shall
Now seeming sweet convert to bitter gall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: To JULIET If I profane with my unworthiest hand
This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this:
My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand
To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much,
Which mannerly devotion shows in this;
For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch,
And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do;
They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take.
Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Sin from thy lips? O trespass sweetly urged!
Give me my sin again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: You kiss by the book.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What is her mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, bachelor,
Her mother is the lady of the house,
And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous
I nursed her daughter, that you talk'd withal;
I tell you, he that can lay hold of her
Shall have the chinks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Is she a Capulet?
O dear account! my life is my foe's debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Away, begone; the sport is at the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CAPULET
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone;
We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.
Is it e'en so? why, then, I thank you all
I thank you, honest gentlemen; good night.
More torches here! Come on then, let's to bed.
Ah, sirrah, by my fay, it waxes late:
I'll to my rest.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt all but JULIET and Nurse

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, nurse. What is yond gentleman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that now is going out of door?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, that, I think, be young Petrucio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that follows there, that would not dance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Go ask his name: if he be married.
My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: His name is Romeo, and a Montague;
The only son of your great enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: My only love sprung from my only hate!
Too early seen unknown, and known too late!
Prodigious birth of love it is to me,
That I must love a loathed enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: What's this? what's this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: A rhyme I learn'd even now
Of one I danced withal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Anon, anon!
Come, let's away; the strangers all are gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chorus
SPEECH.LINE: Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie,
And young affection gapes to be his heir;
That fair for which love groan'd for and would die,
With tender Juliet match'd, is now not fair.
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again,
Alike betwitched by the charm of looks,
But to his foe supposed he must complain,
And she steal love's sweet bait from fearful hooks:
Being held a foe, he may not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;
And she as much in love, her means much less
To meet her new-beloved any where:
But passion lends them power, time means, to meet
Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. A lane by the wall of Capulet's orchard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Can I go forward when my heart is here?
Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He climbs the wall, and leaps down within it

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo! my cousin Romeo!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: He is wise;
And, on my lie, hath stol'n him home to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: He ran this way, and leap'd this orchard wall:
Call, good Mercutio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I'll conjure too.
Romeo! humours! madman! passion! lover!
Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh:
Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied;
Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'
Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
One nick-name for her purblind son and heir,
Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim,
When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not;
The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.
I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes,
By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,
By her fine foot, straight leg and quivering thigh
And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,
That in thy likeness thou appear to us!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him
To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle
Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
Till she had laid it and conjured it down;
That were some spite: my invocation
Is fair and honest, and in his mistress' name
I conjure only but to raise up him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees,
To be consorted with the humorous night:
Blind is his love and best befits the dark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
Now will he sit under a medlar tree,
And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.
Romeo, that she were, O, that she were
An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!
Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;
This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep:
Come, shall we go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Go, then; for 'tis in vain
To seek him here that means not to be found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: JULIET appears above at a window
SPEECH.LINE: But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks?
It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,
Who is already sick and pale with grief,
That thou her maid art far more fair than she:
Be not her maid, since she is envious;
Her vestal livery is but sick and green
And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.
It is my lady, O, it is my love!
O, that she knew she were!
She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?
Her eye discourses; I will answer it.
I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks:
Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,
Having some business, do entreat her eyes
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
What if her eyes were there, they in her head?
The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars,
As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven
Would through the airy region stream so bright
That birds would sing and think it were not night.
See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!
O, that I were a glove upon that hand,
That I might touch that cheek!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: She speaks:
O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art
As glorious to this night, being o'er my head
As is a winged messenger of heaven
Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes
Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
And sails upon the bosom of the air.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?
Deny thy father and refuse thy name;
Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Aside Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;
Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.
What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor foot,
Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part
Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!
What's in a name? that which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet;
So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,
Retain that dear perfection which he owes
Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,
And for that name which is no part of thee
Take all myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I take thee at thy word:
Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized;
Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night
So stumblest on my counsel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: By a name
I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,
Because it is an enemy to thee;
Had I it written, I would tear the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound:
Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
And the place death, considering who thou art,
If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls;
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
And what love can do that dares love attempt;
Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye
Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet,
And I am proof against their enmity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight;
And but thou love me, let them find me here:
My life were better ended by their hate,
Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: By whose direction found'st thou out this place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire;
He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.
I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far
As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea,
I would adventure for such merchandise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face,
Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night
Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny
What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,'
And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st,
Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries
Then say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,
If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully:
Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,
I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay,
So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.
In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,
And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light:
But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true
Than those that have more cunning to be strange.
I should have been more strange, I must confess,
But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware,
My true love's passion: therefore pardon me,
And not impute this yielding to light love,
Which the dark night hath so discovered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear
That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon,
That monthly changes in her circled orb,
Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What shall I swear by?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Do not swear at all;
Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
Which is the god of my idolatry,
And I'll believe thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: If my heart's dear love--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee,
I have no joy of this contract to-night:
It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;
Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night!
This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath,
May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest
Come to thy heart as that within my breast!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:
And yet I would it were to give again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: But to be frank, and give it thee again.
And yet I wish but for the thing I have:
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep; the more I give to thee,
The more I have, for both are infinite.
I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu!
Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true.
Stay but a little, I will come again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard.
Being in night, all this is but a dream,
Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
If that thy bent of love be honourable,
Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow,
By one that I'll procure to come to thee,
Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite;
And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay
And follow thee my lord throughout the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Within Madam!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well,
I do beseech thee--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Within Madam!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: By and by, I come:--
To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief:
To-morrow will I send.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: So thrive my soul--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand times good night!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.
Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from
their books,
But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice,
To lure this tassel-gentle back again!
Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;
Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,
And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,
With repetition of my Romeo's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: It is my soul that calls upon my name:
How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,
Like softest music to attending ears!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: My dear?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: At what o'clock to-morrow
Shall I send to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: At the hour of nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.
I have forgot why I did call thee back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,
Remembering how I love thy company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget,
Forgetting any other home but this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone:
And yet no further than a wanton's bird;
Who lets it hop a little from her hand,
Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,
And with a silk thread plucks it back again,
So loving-jealous of his liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were thy bird.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet, so would I:
Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
Good night, good night! parting is such
sweet sorrow,
That I shall say good night till it be morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast!
Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!
Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell,
His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE III. Friar Laurence's cell.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE, with a basket

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,
And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels
From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,
I must up-fill this osier cage of ours
With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;
What is her burying grave that is her womb,
And from her womb children of divers kind
We sucking on her natural bosom find,
Many for many virtues excellent,
None but for some and yet all different.
O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:
For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
But to the earth some special good doth give,
Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;
And vice sometimes by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this small flower
Poison hath residence and medicine power:
For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;
Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.
Two such opposed kings encamp them still
In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Benedicite!
What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
Young son, it argues a distemper'd head
So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye,
And where care lodges, sleep will never lie;
But where unbruised youth with unstuff'd brain
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign:
Therefore thy earliness doth me assure
Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;
Or if not so, then here I hit it right,
Our Romeo hath not been in bed to-night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: With Rosaline, my ghostly father? no;
I have forgot that name, and that name's woe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I'll tell thee, ere thou ask it me again.
I have been feasting with mine enemy,
Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,
That's by me wounded: both our remedies
Within thy help and holy physic lies:
I bear no hatred, blessed man, for, lo,
My intercession likewise steads my foe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift;
Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set
On the fair daughter of rich Capulet:
As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine;
And all combined, save what thou must combine
By holy marriage: when and where and how
We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow,
I'll tell thee as we pass; but this I pray,
That thou consent to marry us to-day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear,
So soon forsaken? young men's love then lies
Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
Jesu Maria, what a deal of brine
Hath wash'd thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline!
How much salt water thrown away in waste,
To season love, that of it doth not taste!
The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears,
Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears;
Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit
Of an old tear that is not wash'd off yet:
If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine,
Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline:
And art thou changed? pronounce this sentence then,
Women may fall, when there's no strength in men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: And bad'st me bury love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Not in a grave,
To lay one in, another out to have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee, chide not; she whom I love now
Doth grace for grace and love for love allow;
The other did not so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: O, she knew well
Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.
But come, young waverer, come, go with me,
In one respect I'll thy assistant be;
For this alliance may so happy prove,
To turn your households' rancour to pure love.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O, let us hence; I stand on sudden haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Where the devil should this Romeo be?
Came he not home to-night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline.
Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Tybalt, the kinsman of old Capulet,
Hath sent a letter to his father's house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: A challenge, on my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo will answer it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he
dares, being dared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poor Romeo! he is already dead; stabbed with a
white wench's black eye; shot through the ear with a
love-song; the very pin of his heart cleft with the
blind bow-boy's butt-shaft: and is he a man to
encounter Tybalt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what is Tybalt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: More than prince of cats, I can tell you. O, he is
the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as
you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and
proportion; rests me his minim rest, one, two, and
the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk
button, a duellist, a duellist; a gentleman of the
very first house, of the first and second cause:
ah, the immortal passado! the punto reverso! the
hai!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: The what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: The pox of such antic, lisping, affecting
fantasticoes; these new tuners of accents! 'By Jesu,
a very good blade! a very tall man! a very good
whore!' Why, is not this a lamentable thing,
grandsire, that we should be thus afflicted with
these strange flies, these fashion-mongers, these
perdona-mi's, who stand so much on the new form,
that they cannot at ease on the old bench? O, their
bones, their bones!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Without his roe, like a dried herring: flesh, flesh,
how art thou fishified! Now is he for the numbers
that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his lady was but a
kitchen-wench; marry, she had a better love to
be-rhyme her; Dido a dowdy; Cleopatra a gipsy;
Helen and Hero hildings and harlots; Thisbe a grey
eye or so, but not to the purpose. Signior
Romeo, bon jour! there's a French salutation
to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit
fairly last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: The ship, sir, the slip; can you not conceive?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, good Mercutio, my business was great; and in
such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to say, such a case as yours
constrains a man to bow in the hams.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Meaning, to court'sy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast most kindly hit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: A most courteous exposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Pink for flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, then is my pump well flowered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Well said: follow me this jest now till thou hast
worn out thy pump, that when the single sole of it
is worn, the jest may remain after the wearing sole singular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the
singleness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Come between us, good Benvolio; my wits faint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs; or I'll cry a match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if thy wits run the wild-goose chase, I have
done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of
thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five:
was I with you there for the goose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wast never with me for any thing when thou wast
not there for the goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good goose, bite not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most
sharp sauce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: And is it not well served in to a sweet goose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: O here's a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an
inch narrow to an ell broad!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I stretch it out for that word 'broad;' which added
to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?
now art thou sociable, now art thou Romeo; now art
thou what thou art, by art as well as by nature:
for this drivelling love is like a great natural,
that runs lolling up and down to hide his bauble in a hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Stop there, stop there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: O, thou art deceived; I would have made it short:
for I was come to the whole depth of my tale; and
meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Here's goodly gear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: A sail, a sail!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Two, two; a shirt and a smock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Peter!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PETER
SPEECH.LINE: Anon!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: My fan, Peter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Good Peter, to hide her face; for her fan's the
fairer face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: God ye good den, fair gentlewoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Is it good den?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: 'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the
dial is now upon the prick of noon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Out upon you! what a man are you!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made for himself to
mar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth, it is well said; 'for himself to mar,'
quoth a'? Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I
may find the young Romeo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I can tell you; but young Romeo will be older when
you have found him than he was when you sought him:
I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: You say well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, is the worst well? very well took, i' faith;
wisely, wisely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: if you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with
you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: She will indite him to some supper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! so ho!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What hast thou found?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: No hare, sir; unless a hare, sir, in a lenten pie,
that is something stale and hoar ere it be spent.
An old hare hoar,
And an old hare hoar,
Is very good meat in lent
But a hare that is hoar
Is too much for a score,
When it hoars ere it be spent.
Romeo, will you come to your father's? we'll
to dinner, thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I will follow you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, ancient lady; farewell,
'lady, lady, lady.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, farewell! I pray you, sir, what saucy
merchant was this, that was so full of his ropery?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: A gentleman, nurse, that loves to hear himself talk,
and will speak more in a minute than he will stand
to in a month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: An a' speak any thing against me, I'll take him
down, an a' were lustier than he is, and twenty such
Jacks; and if I cannot, I'll find those that shall.
Scurvy knave! I am none of his flirt-gills; I am
none of his skains-mates. And thou must stand by
too, and suffer every knave to use me at his pleasure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PETER
SPEECH.LINE: I saw no man use you a pleasure; if I had, my weapon
should quickly have been out, I warrant you: I dare
draw as soon as another man, if I see occasion in a
good quarrel, and the law on my side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Now, afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about
me quivers. Scurvy knave! Pray you, sir, a word:
and as I told you, my young lady bade me inquire you
out; what she bade me say, I will keep to myself:
but first let me tell ye, if ye should lead her into
a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross
kind of behavior, as they say: for the gentlewoman
is young; and, therefore, if you should deal double
with her, truly it were an ill thing to be offered
to any gentlewoman, and very weak dealing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress. I
protest unto thee--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Good heart, and, i' faith, I will tell her as much:
Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou tell her, nurse? thou dost not mark me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest; which, as
I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Bid her devise
Some means to come to shrift this afternoon;
And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell
Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: No truly sir; not a penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Go to; I say you shall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: This afternoon, sir? well, she shall be there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: And stay, good nurse, behind the abbey wall:
Within this hour my man shall be with thee
And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair;
Which to the high top-gallant of my joy
Must be my convoy in the secret night.
Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains:
Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Now God in heaven bless thee! Hark you, sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: What say'st thou, my dear nurse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Is your man secret? Did you ne'er hear say,
Two may keep counsel, putting one away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant thee, my man's as true as steel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: NURSE
SPEECH.LINE: Well, sir; my mistress is the sweetest lady--Lord,
Lord! when 'twas a little prating thing:--O, there
is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain
lay knife aboard; but she, good soul, had as lief
see a toad, a very toad, as see him. I anger her
sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer
man; but, I'll warrant you, when I say so, she looks
as pale as any clout in the versal world. Doth not
rosemary and Romeo begin both with a letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, nurse; what of that? both with an R.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Ah. mocker! that's the dog's name; R is for
the--No; I know it begins with some other
letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of
it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good
to hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Commend me to thy lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Ay, a thousand times.
Peter!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PETER
SPEECH.LINE: Anon!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse;
In half an hour she promised to return.
Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so.
O, she is lame! love's heralds should be thoughts,
Which ten times faster glide than the sun's beams,
Driving back shadows over louring hills:
Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love,
And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.
Now is the sun upon the highmost hill
Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve
Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
Had she affections and warm youthful blood,
She would be as swift in motion as a ball;
My words would bandy her to my sweet love,
And his to me:
But old folks, many feign as they were dead;
Unwieldy, slow, heavy and pale as lead.
O God, she comes!
O honey nurse, what news?
Hast thou met with him? Send thy man away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Peter, stay at the gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good sweet nurse,--O Lord, why look'st thou sad?
Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily;
If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news
By playing it to me with so sour a face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: I am a-weary, give me leave awhile:
Fie, how my bones ache! what a jaunt have I had!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou hadst my bones, and I thy news:
Nay, come, I pray thee, speak; good, good nurse, speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Jesu, what haste? can you not stay awhile?
Do you not see that I am out of breath?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breath
To say to me that thou art out of breath?
The excuse that thou dost make in this delay
Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
Is thy news good, or bad? answer to that;
Say either, and I'll stay the circumstance:
Let me be satisfied, is't good or bad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you have made a simple choice; you know not
how to choose a man: Romeo! no, not he; though his
face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels
all men's; and for a hand, and a foot, and a body,
though they be not to be talked on, yet they are
past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy,
but, I'll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb. Go thy
ways, wench; serve God. What, have you dined at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: No, no: but all this did I know before.
What says he of our marriage? what of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Lord, how my head aches! what a head have I!
It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces.
My back o' t' other side,--O, my back, my back!
Beshrew your heart for sending me about,
To catch my death with jaunting up and down!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.
Sweet, sweet, sweet nurse, tell me, what says my love?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a
courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I
warrant, a virtuous,--Where is your mother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my mother! why, she is within;
Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!
'Your love says, like an honest gentleman,
Where is your mother?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: O God's lady dear!
Are you so hot? marry, come up, I trow;
Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
Henceforward do your messages yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Here's such a coil! come, what says Romeo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Have you got leave to go to shrift to-day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nurse
SPEECH.LINE: Then hie you hence to Friar Laurence' cell;
There stays a husband to make you a wife:
Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks,
They'll be in scarlet straight at any news.
Hie you to church; I must another way,
To fetch a ladder, by the which your love
Must climb a bird's nest soon when it is dark:
I am the drudge and toil in your delight,
But you shall bear the burden soon at night.
Go; I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Hie to high fortune! Honest nurse, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: So smile the heavens upon this holy act,
That after hours with sorrow chide us not!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, amen! but come what sorrow can,
It cannot countervail the exchange of joy
That one short minute gives me in her sight:
Do thou but close our hands with holy words,
Then love-devouring death do what he dare;
It is enough I may but call her mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: These violent delights have violent ends
And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,
Which as they kiss consume: the sweetest honey
Is loathsome in his own deliciousness
And in the taste confounds the appetite:
Therefore love moderately; long love doth so;
Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
Here comes the lady: O, so light a foot
Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint:
A lover may bestride the gossamer
That idles in the wanton summer air,
And yet not fall; so light is vanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Good even to my ghostly confessor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy
Be heap'd like mine and that thy skill be more
To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath
This neighbour air, and let rich music's tongue
Unfold the imagined happiness that both
Receive in either by this dear encounter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JULIET
SPEECH.LINE: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,
Brags of his substance, not of ornament:
They are but beggars that can count their worth;
But my true love is grown to such excess
I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: FRIAR LAURENCE
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come with me, and we will make short work;
For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone
Till holy church incorporate two in one.

SCENE.TITLE: SCENE I. A public place.
SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, Page, and Servants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire:
The day is hot, the Capulets abroad,
And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl;
For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art like one of those fellows that when he
enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword
upon the table and says 'God send me no need of
thee!' and by the operation of the second cup draws
it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: Am I like such a fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as
any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as
soon moody to be moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: And what to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none
shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou! why,
thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more,
or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast: thou
wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no
other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what
eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of
meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as
an egg for quarrelling: thou hast quarrelled with a
man for coughing in the street, because he hath
wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:
didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing
his new doublet before Easter? with another, for
tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou
wilt tutor me from quarrelling!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man
should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: The fee-simple! O simple!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: By my head, here come the Capulets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: By my heel, I care not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.
Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: And but one word with one of us? couple it with
something; make it a word and a blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you
will give me occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an
thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but
discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall
make you dance. 'Zounds, consort!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BENVOLIO
SPEECH.LINE: We talk here in the public haunt of men:
Either withdraw unto some private place,
And reason coldly of your grievances,
Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze;
I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MERCUTIO
SPEECH.LINE: But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery:
Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower;
Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford
No better term than this,--thou art a villain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
To such a greeting: villain am I none;
Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TYBALT
SPEECH.LINE: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries
That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROMEO
SPEECH.LINE: I do protest, I never injured thee,
But love thee better than thou canst devise,
